author: Chris Waugh
title: Rafa Benitez's sole aim for 2016-17 is promotion - but the Newcastle boss has longer-term ambitions
text:
Newcastle United's wait for a trophy currently stands at 47 years, but it looks set to pass the half-century mark Shares Get Newcastle United FC news by email Newcastle United manager Rafa Benitez 
An awful lot has happened since the last time Newcastle United lifted a major piece of silverware. 
In fact, if ‘Brexit’ is the outcome of this month’s referendum then this country will have joined the European project, voted to stay in it 41 years ago, and then gone full circle and decided to leave - all within the time it has taken the Magpies to add to their trophy haul. 
There have been a couple of Texaco Cups, an Anglo-Italian Cup, two second-tier titles, and even the UEFA Intertoto Cup - but no major trophy since 1969. 
On June 11, 1969, Bob Moncur - now a member of the Newcastle board - held aloft the Inter-Cities Fairs Cup in the Megyeri uti Stadium in Budapest following the Magpies’ 6-2 aggregate victory over Ujpesti Dozsa. 
Newcastle supporters’ wait for further now glory stands at 47 years and counting. 
It will be a minimum of 48 by the time it is ended, and even that would require a second-tier Magpies side to triumph against the odds in either the FA Cup or League Cup next season, while focusing their main attentions on achieving automatic promotion back to the top flight. 
At the moment, it looks like that wait will reach at least the half-century mark. 
For a club who get 52,000 fans through the gate every week in the Premier League - and can expect in the late-40,000s in the Championship next season - that is simply staggering. 
Throughout their history, United have won the FA Cup on six occasions - the last of which was in 1955 - and they have also lifted the top-flight title four times, but the most recent of those triumphs was 89 years ago. 
For now, Newcastle’s focus is on one prize and one prize alone: promotion. 
If that brings with it a second Championship crown in eight seasons, then even better. 
But Rafa Benitez’s sole priority at the moment is to get the Magpies back into the top flight. Our big Rafa Benitez interview
